data.title: Aly and AJ Michalka Talk Post-Disney Life and New Music
data.meta_description: Sisters Aly and AJ Michalka grew up in front of the camera, and now the former teen stars are welcoming adulthood with open arms. The duo sits down with Krista Smith to talk about their new band 78violet, the importance of family, and life after Disney.
data.text:
(upbeat music)

[Woman] And you look on that top one Wait a second...

Okay

(camera shutters)

The talent I would most like to have would be

perfect memory.

Really? Literally

being able to remember every single...

Is that a talent or a super

hero power?

My greatest fear is...

Death by fire.

Geez.

Yeah.

Getting dark.

I know, sorry.

The words and phrases I most overuse are

legit.

Oh you do.

[AJ] Too much.

I am sitting here with Aly and AJ Michalka

who are here to talk about a lot of things.

Their new band, their new album, coming up,

their acting career, their life,

and their mother who was an NFL cheerleader

who in another life (Aly and AJ laugh)

that's what I wanna be.

Did you guys cheer at all in high school

or did you do any of that?

We were homeschooled from sixth grade on

so AJ was in fourth, I was in sixth.

And I mean, our afterschool activities kinda consisted of

piano lessons, music class, acting class.

What's it like being homeschooled?

I think that it's right for certain kids.

There is that cliche of the homeschool kid who's

hiding under a rock.

That's like a weirdo-- But I think if you have that

personality and you're really shy,

it's not the best.

Yeah.

Way for you to get an education (mumbles)

What was the decision to do it,

were you working at the time?

For us it's just hours of homework that was

so unnecessary that my mom kept asking,

what are you guys do in school?

I'm so confused.

You go to school for six-seven hours and then

you come back with four hours of homework.

This is ridiculous.

She just wanted so bad to have those kids that

could just come home and do a little bit of homework

and then cook a home cooked meal and the kids

could take a bath, and the family could watch a movie

after, and we didn't get that.

Until we were homeschooled.

You aren't necessarily my demographic.

I didn't know about when you're doing the soundtrack

for High School Musical, and your albums

have gone platinum, but doing my homework on you two,

it is staggering.

I mean, you wrote your own music at such a young age.

You guys were Aly and AJ, that was your show.

And you kinda came up through Hollywood Records

which was owned by Disney.

How was that navigating through the Disney system?

Through the synergy of the channel and through

Radio Disney, and through just that cross-promotion,

they were able to really get a huge fan base

following us.

As we got older and we grew up, it became a little bit more

difficult because we started becoming older women.

And we had a different sense of taste than we did

at the beginning.

And I think that that is when it became a little of

a struggle.

Just felt like we had outgrown where we were.

And I think that they really truly understood that

at the end of the day, and that's why

we ended up parting ways.

I really like that we got out when we did,

because I think if we had been there any longer,

I think that we would've been putting up music

that we never really truly have our heart in.

Alice and Amanda, that's who we are as people.

Aly and AJ Michalka, sure that's who we are as actors.

But when it comes to being a band,

78Violet kinda represents our music

and us as individuals.

[Krista] How'd you come up with it?

78 actually stands for platinum,

and it really represents our relationship as sisters,

which is cool, it's non corrodable, it's

a material that can't be tarnished.

And violet has always been this, really royal

spiritual color for us, that's kind of

followed us in every home and on walls

and so together we just figured that that was a really

kind of personal power--

We just linked them together and then we thought

okay, maybe that's it.

Not only do we work together everyday, but we are

able to enjoy each other

when we come home in the same house.

So it's nice, we have our own little rooms,

and our own areas and we try not to

share every single life moment together

'cause I think it's more special when you can

have that separation

and then come together at the end of the day

but I do, I love working with Aly,

she's such a smart, creative person,

and we've gone through a lot together

which has been really cool.

(film reel spinning)

[Both Aly and AJ] Idea of perfect happiness.

Family.

Yeah.

A solid family--

I would say having family, having kids,

having a husband.

I consider my greatest achievement to be

sisterhood.

Yeah! Yay!

Woohoo!

And performing at the White House.

Yeah, that's pretty cool.

Yeah.

That's legit.

(film reel spinning)

(lounge music)
